  1. Introduction

    Flexbox and Grid are two types of css layout. 

        element {
        display: flex;
    }
    element {
        display: grid;
    }
    They are very useful for designing responsive web pages.

    Grid is intended for large scale layouts, flexbox is intended for local layout.

    For example, a Youtube homepage like webpage may use grid to arrange the positions of videos, and use flexbox to arrange the info box (e.g. title, author, duration ...) for each video.

  2. Flexbox

    1. flexbox is a one-direction layout: either in row direction or column direction.
    Since the screen width is not infinite, row direction can be configured as wrap.

    2. To apply flexbox, there should be a container with display:flex and serveral items

    Container

    The container can control
    layout direction flex-direction,
    main-axis alignment (horizontal) justify-content
    Within a row, cross-axis alignment (Vertical) align-items
    cross-asix row alignment align-content

    Example

    1. container 

                        #example1{
                        display: flex; 
                        width:600px; 
                        height: auto;
                        background-color: green;
                        flex-direction: row;
                        flex-wrap: nowrap;
                        overflow:scroll;
                    }

    width:300px; height: 180px;background-color:red;word-wrap: break-word;
    width:100px; height: 200px;background-color:blue;word-wrap: break-word;
    width:130px; height: 300px;background-color:yellow;word-wrap: break-word;
    width:130px; height: 300px;background-color:steelblue;word-wrap: break-word;
    width:130px; height: 300px;background-color:slateblue;word-wrap: break-word;
    1. flex-wrap: default is nowrap.
      What happens if item width exceed container width when nowrap?
      1. some items width will be reduced if the min-wdith is not set.
      2. extra items will overflow the container. (container overflow:hidden/scroll)

    2. container 

                        #example2{
                        display: flex; 
                        width:600px; 
                        height: 500px;
                        background-color: green;
                        flex-direction: row;
                        align-items: flex-start; // align item within a row
                        flex-wrap: wrap;
                        overflow:scroll;
                    }

    width:300px; height: 100px;background-color:red;word-wrap: break-word;
    width:100px; height: 130px;background-color:blue;word-wrap: break-word;
    width:130px; height: 200px;background-color:yellow;word-wrap: break-word;
    width:130px; height: 200px;background-color:steelblue;word-wrap: break-word;
    width:130px; height: auto;background-color:slateblue;word-wrap: break-word;
    1. container height is larger the total height. container height 500px, required height is 200px + 200px
      row cross-axis alignment is controlled by align-content, here is default stretch.
      stretch does not change the item's height, it change the row height.
      ** no effect if only a single row.
    2. align-items: control item's cross-asix alignment within a row.
      stretch: make items height to rwo height if item's height is auto.
    3. align-content controls rows, align-items controls items within a row

  3. Grid

    Grid is a two dimensional layout.

    container define the layout with items' names, item declare its name
